item.title: Multi-country outbreak of mpox, External situation report #45 - 11 January 2025 - World Health Organization
item.description:
Multi-country outbreak of mpox, External situation report #45 - 11 January 2025

Date: 11 January 2025 | Source: WHO Emergency Situational Updates

This is the 45th situation report for the multi-country outbreak of mpox, which provides details on the latest epidemiological trends. The outbreak of clade Ib monkeypox virus (MPXV) continues predominantly in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Burundi and Uganda, with new travel-related cases identified in previously unaffected countries.

  • The outbreak is largely centered in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Burundi, and Uganda.
  • New travel-related cases have been reported in unaffected countries.
  • Strengthened surveillance and timely reporting is necessary to prevent international spread.
“Recent travel-associated mpox cases highlight the risk of undetected transmission.”

The situation underscores the importance of global monitoring and improving surveillance systems against mpox.

item.title: Assam reports first HMPV case this season as 10-month-old child tests positive in Dibrugarh - Hindustan Times
item.description:
Assam Reports First Case of HMPV Infection This Season

Date: Jan 11, 2025 | Source: Hindustan Times

Assam has reported its first case of human metapneumovirus (HMPV) infection this season, with a 10-month-old child testing positive. The infant is currently undergoing treatment at Assam Medical College and Hospital (AMCH) in Dibrugarh and is said to be stable.

  • Ten-month-old child tests positive for HMPV in Dibrugarh, Assam.
  • Child admitted to AMCH with cold-related symptoms four days ago.
  • HMPV infection confirmed by ICMR-RMRC Lahowal after routine tests.
  • HMPV is a common respiratory virus that usually causes mild symptoms.
  • Similar HMPV cases reported in Gujarat, Maharashtra, Karnataka, and Tamil Nadu.
“The HMPV infection was confirmed yesterday after we got test results from Lahowal-based ICMR-RMRC. The child is stable now. It is a common virus, and there is nothing to worry about.” - Dr. Dhrubajyoti Bhuyan, AMCH superintendent

The detection of HMPV is not unusual, as the virus circulates seasonally and typically impacts infants and individuals with weaker immune systems more severely.

item.title: 6 benefits of eating 2 dates every day - The Times of India
item.description:
6 Benefits of Eating 2 Dates Every Day

Publication Date: October 2023 Source: Unknown

This article explores the numerous health benefits associated with consuming two dates daily, suggesting that this simple dietary addition can promote well-being.

  • Rich in nutrients and energy-boosting carbohydrates.
  • High in dietary fiber which aids digestion.
  • Contains antioxidants that support overall health.
  • May help regulate blood sugar levels.
  • Good for heart health due to high potassium content.
  • Can enhance brain health and cognitive function.
“Incorporating dates into your diet can be a simple yet effective way to enhance your nutrition.”

In conclusion, adding two dates to your daily diet can offer a variety of health benefits, making it a small but impactful change.

item.title: Why a full moon might mess with your sleep, according to science - VOGUE India
item.description:
Why a full moon might mess with your sleep, according to science

Publication Date: Not specified | Source: self.com

Research indicates that a full moon may disrupt sleep, with studies showing that individuals take longer to fall asleep and experience less deep sleep during this lunar phase.

  • A study in 2013 revealed that on full moon nights, people took five minutes longer to fall asleep and had 30% less deep sleep.
  • A 2014 study confirmed similar findings, with participants getting an average of 25 minutes less sleep during full moons.
  • The reasons behind this phenomenon are debated, with theories including evolutionary adaptations and the moon’s gravitational effects.
“When our ancestors were hunting and gathering, it was highly adaptive to extend the end of the day.” - Dr. Horacio de la Iglesia

To mitigate sleep disruptions, experts recommend adjusting bedtime and maintaining good sleep practices.

item.title: Highlights | HMPV Cases in India Live: Total Case Count Increases To 13, 2 New HMPV Virus Reported; - Zee News
item.description:
HMPV Cases in India Increase: Total Case Count Reaches 13

Last Updated: Jan 11, 2025 | Source: Zee News

The number of reported HMPV cases in India has now reached 13, with health officials closely monitoring the situation following multiple reports across different states.

  • Two new HMPV cases reported in Bengaluru.
  • Total of 13 cases confirmed, including reports from Gujarat, Chennai, Kolkata, Nagpur, and Mumbai.
  • Union Health Minister stated that HMPV has been circulating worldwide since its identification in 2001.
  • Health authorities are prepared for potential outbreaks, especially with upcoming large gatherings like the Mahakumbh.
  • HMPV RT-PCR test costs range from Rs 3,000 to Rs 8,000, with comprehensive tests costing up to Rs 20,000.
"The Human Metapneumovirus (HMPV) is not a new virus," - Union Health Minister JP Nadda.

As the case count rises, health officials emphasize readiness to manage respiratory illness spikes and urge public vigilance during major events.

item.title: Simple steps to quit sugar in your diet - The Times of India
item.description:
Simple Steps to Quit Sugar in Your Diet

Published on: Not specified Source: Not specified

This article outlines practical strategies for reducing sugar intake, aiming to improve overall health.

  • Identify sources of hidden sugars in common foods.
  • Gradually reduce sugar consumption rather than quitting cold turkey.
  • Replace sugary snacks with healthier alternatives.
  • Monitor your mood and physical responses as you cut back.
"Reducing sugar can lead to improved energy levels and better mood."

In conclusion, implementing small changes towards reducing sugar can have significant health benefits over time.

item.title: ‘Drink your coffee, but only in the morning’: What a new study says - The Indian Express
item.description:
‘Drink your coffee, but only in the morning’: What a new study says

Date: January 8, 2025 Source: The Indian Express

A new study indicates that drinking coffee in the morning may lead to significant health benefits, including a reduced mortality risk. Conducted on over 42,000 adults, it highlights the importance of timing in coffee consumption.

  • The study found morning coffee drinkers had a 16% lower mortality risk and a 31% lower risk of death from cardiovascular disease compared to non-drinkers.
  • It suggests that the timing of coffee consumption may be more crucial than the quantity consumed.
  • Data from the US National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey was analyzed, confirming the findings.
  • Potential reasons include coffee's impact on sleep quality and inflammatory responses in the body.
“It’s not just whether you drink coffee or how much you drink, but the time of day when you drink coffee that’s important.” - Lu Qi, study author

This study reinforces the idea that morning coffee consumption could play a role in enhancing health and longevity.

item.title: Govt lab confirms HMPV infection in 8-yr-old, cases rise to three in Gujarat - The Indian Express
item.description:
Govt lab confirms HMPV infection in 8-yr-old, cases rise to three in Gujarat

Date: January 11, 2025

Source: Indian Express

An eight-year-old boy from Gujarat’s Sabarkantha district has contracted human metapneumovirus infection, bringing the total number of cases in the state to three. Health authorities had sent his blood samples to a government lab for confirmation after initial testing.

  • The boy is a farm laborer's child from Prantij taluka.
  • He is hospitalized in Himmatnagar and his condition is stable.
  • The first case in Gujarat was reported on January 6 in a two-month-old boy.
  • An 80-year-old man also tested positive for HMPV in Ahmedabad.
  • HMPV spreads through respiratory droplets and contact with infected individuals.
“The government lab on Friday confirmed that the boy is infected with HMPV. He is currently under treatment and his condition is stable,” said Sabarkantha District Collector Ratankanvar Gadhavicharan.

The rising cases of HMPV in Gujarat highlight the importance of awareness and early detection of respiratory pathogens.

item.title: Best Immune-Boosting Foods to Eat During Winter to Help You Stay Healthy - Healthline
item.description:
Best Immune-Boosting Foods to Eat During Winter to Help You Stay Healthy

Date: October 2023 | Source: Healthline

As winter approaches, maintaining a robust immune system is crucial due to the increase in respiratory illnesses. This article highlights various nutrient-rich foods that can help bolster immunity during the winter months.

  • Certain whole foods are vital for health in winter.
  • Foods like root vegetables, citrus, nuts, and berries are rich in vitamins and antioxidants.
  • A strong immune system is essential to combat respiratory illnesses prevalent in colder climates.
William Schaffner, MD: “We spend more time indoors, crowded together during the winter… These close personal contacts provide ample opportunities for these respiratory viruses to spread.”

Maintaining a balanced diet year-round is important, but specific attention to winter nutrition can enhance immunity. Experts recommend increasing consumption of vitamin D, A, and C to prevent infections.

item.title: Can HMPV affect your kidneys? Signs and symptoms to watch out for - The Times of India
item.description:
Can HMPV affect your kidneys? Signs and symptoms to watch out for

Publication Date: October 2023 Source: [Source Name]

HMPV (Human Metapneumovirus) can lead to serious kidney issues; understanding symptoms is crucial.

  • HMPV is a respiratory virus that may also impact kidney function.
  • Common symptoms include cough, fever, and shortness of breath.
  • Patients should monitor for unusual urination or swelling.
  • Healthcare providers recommend seeking advice if symptoms escalate.
“Understanding the signs of HMPV can prevent severe health complications.”

The awareness of HMPV’s effects on kidneys highlights the need for vigilance among affected individuals.

item.title: Is your blood sugar spiralling even when you are of the right body weight? Here’s what you need to know about lean diabetes - The Indian Express
item.description:
Is your blood sugar spiralling even when you are of the right body weight? Here’s what you need to know about lean diabetes

Published on: January 10, 2025, Source: The Indian Express

This article discusses lean diabetes, its causes, complications, and significance, highlighting research findings and the importance of recognizing this condition.

  • Multiple triggers for lean diabetes may include pancreatic disorders, low birth weight, and malnutrition.
  • Lean diabetes can lead to severe complications like neuropathy, retinopathy, and nephropathy, and often occurs at a younger age.
  • A study indicated that prevalence varied significantly with socio-economic status, from 11.6% in the poorest to 1.1% in the richest.
  • Research indicates that a significant percentage of men and women are affected by elevated blood glucose levels, with a specific concern about lean diabetes among Type 2 diabetics.
  • Experts stress the need for more awareness about the various sub-types of diabetes affecting lean individuals.
“Diabetes is a consortium of multiple diseases which may be caused by different mechanisms.” - Dr. Nihal Thomas

Understanding lean diabetes is crucial for effective management and public health implications, especially as rates of diabetes continue to rise globally.

item.title: Cambodian man dies from bird flu - Medical Xpress
item.description:
Cambodian Man Dies from H5N1 Bird Flu After Consuming Sick Chickens

Date: January 10, 2025 Source: Medical Xpress

A 28-year-old man from Kampong Cham province, Cambodia, has died from bird flu after consuming sick chickens. He tested positive for the H5N1 virus.

  • The patient exhibited critical symptoms including fever, coughing, and difficulty breathing.
  • In 2023, at least three people in Cambodia have died from bird flu, including a two-year-old girl.
  • The World Health Organization has warned about inadequate influenza surveillance in relation to H5N1.
  • The victim had raised poultry and reportedly cooked sick chickens for food.
  • Authorities are investigating the outbreak and urging vigilance among the public.
"Bird flu H5N1 remains a threat to the health of our people." - Cambodian Health Ministry

The ongoing global outbreak of H5N1 has led to severe outbreaks in Europe and the Americas, resulting in the culling of millions of domestic poultry and the deaths of tens of thousands of wild birds.

item.title: Tune In, Tune Up: Five Creators Share Tips To Guide Your 2025 Wellness Goals - spotify.com
item.description:
Tune In, Tune Up: Five Creators Share Tips To Guide Your 2025 Wellness Goals

Publication Date: January 2025 | Source: Spotify

The new year is a time for fresh starts and a renewed focus on our well-being. Spotify consulted five luminaries in the wellness space to share their insights and inspire listeners for 2025.

  • Mark Manson: The host of The Subtle Art of Not Giving a F*ck Podcast discusses the importance of breaking big goals into smaller, attainable ones.
  • Liz Moody: In her podcast, she emphasizes diversity in diet for gut health, advocating for 30 plants per week.
  • Gael Aitor and Kayla Suarez: Their podcast GrownKid explores critical topics for Gen Z, focusing on vulnerability and mental health.
  • Tam Kaur: On Self Obsessed, she shares self-development advice for women and emphasizes meditation.
  • Jeremy Godwin: His podcast Let’s Talk About Mental Health provides practical advice for mental wellness and personal growth.
“If you’re relying on willpower, you’re doing it wrong.” - Mark Manson

The insights shared by these creators encourage listeners to engage in small, manageable steps toward their wellness goals and embrace a holistic approach to health and happiness in the new year.

item.title: Woman from Myanmar undergoes liver transplant at hospital in Chennai - The Hindu
item.description:
Woman from Myanmar undergoes liver transplant at hospital in Chennai

Published: January 10, 2025 08:51 pm IST

A 66-year-old woman from Myanmar underwent a liver transplant surgery at a private hospital in Chennai after being diagnosed with advanced liver disease.

  • The woman suffered from ascites, pedal oedema, and jaundice due to hepatitis C virus-induced hepatocellular carcinoma.
  • The surgery was led by Magnus Jayaraj and Karthik Raj M. at GEM Hospitals.
  • A living donor liver transplant was performed with her niece donating a part of her liver.
  • The patient is now recovering and preparing to return to Myanmar.

item.title: Live Updates | HMPV Cases in India Live: Total Case Count Increases To 13, 2 New HMPV Virus Reported - Zee News
item.description:
Live Updates | HMPV Cases in India Live: Total Case Count Increases To 13 2 New HMPV Virus Reported

Last Updated: Jan 10, 2025, 08:49 PM IST | Source: Zee News

The Human Metapneumovirus (HMPV) is causing concern in India as the total case count increases to 13. Authorities are monitoring the situation and providing guidelines.

  • 11 cases reported across various cities: 2 in Bengaluru, 1 in Gujarat, 2 in Chennai, 3 in Kolkata, 2 in Nagpur, and 1 in Mumbai.
  • The virus, first identified in 2001, has been around globally for many years.
  • HMPV RT-PCR tests are priced between Rs 3,000 to Rs 8,000; comprehensive tests can reach Rs 20,000.
  • There are concerns about the spread of HMPV during the Mahakumbh festival attended by millions.
The Union Health Minister noted that the government is prepared to address any potential rise in respiratory illnesses.

Authorities encourage the public to stay informed and vigilant as they navigate this health concern.

item.title: 45-minute sauna lands woman in hospital due to heat stroke - The Times of India
item.description:
Woman Hospitalized After 45-Minute Sauna Session Leads to Heat Stroke

Publication Date: Not specified | Source: Not specified

A woman was hospitalized after suffering from heat stroke following a lengthy sauna session lasting 45 minutes. This incident raises awareness about the risks associated with prolonged exposure to high temperatures.

  • A woman experienced heat stroke after a 45-minute sauna visit.
  • The event underscores the health risks of extended sauna use.
  • Proper hydration and moderation are emphasized for sauna users.
“Users should always listen to their bodies and seek medical attention if they feel unwell.”

This incident serves as a reminder to prioritize safety during sauna use and maintain awareness of personal health limits.
